channel.title: Dollar Store Crafts
channel.description: Cool Craft Ideas from Dollar Store Finds

item.title: Make Crocheted Flower Flip Flops
item.dc:creator: rhonda
item.description: Are you ready for sandal season? I know I am anxious to put my winter boots back in the closet and not think about them until fall! If you need a new pair this year, check out this flip flop makeover from Kara at Petals to Picots. She used some simple crocheting to add pretty flowers to them - and the yarn also pads the ...
item.content:encoded:
Are you ready for sandal season?  I know I am anxious to put my winter boots back in the closet and not think about them until fall!  If you need a new pair this year, check out this flip flop makeover from Kara at Petals to Picots.  She used some simple crocheting to add pretty flowers to them - and the yarn also pads the plastic straps, making them more comfy to wear!  It's a great project for using up odds and ends of scrap yarn.  And it's also a fun way to celebrate the changing of the seasons!  [how to make crocheted flower flip flops]

Project estimate:

  • Flip flop sandals, $1
  • Yarn, on hand or $1 and up

Total:  $1 and up

item.title: Tutorial: Easter Grass Peeps Pops
item.dc:creator: heather
item.description:
Yesterday I showed you the Peeps Terrarium we came up with during our Peeps-inspired crafternoon. Here's another quick and super simple idea for edible crafting with Peeps: Peeps Pops featuring Peeps Bunnies in Grass on a stick. Say that five times fast! Project Materials:
Peeps, $1 Popsicle sticks or pop sticks, $1 and up Shredded coconut, $1 or on hand Green food coloring, $1 or on hand White chocolate melts or ...
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I showed you the Peeps Terrarium we came up with during our Peeps-inspired crafternoon. Here's another quick and super simple idea for edible crafting with Peeps: Peeps Pops featuring Peeps Bunnies in Grass on a stick. Say that five times fast!

Project Materials:

  • Peeps, $1
  • Popsicle sticks or pop sticks, $1 and up
  • Shredded coconut, $1 or on hand
  • Green food coloring, $1 or on hand
  • White chocolate melts or white chocolate chips, about $2 and up

Total: $3 and up

Supplies: You can find Peeps (seasonally) at the dollar store, as well as shredded coconut and food coloring. You can use popsicle sticks or bamboo skewers from the dollar store, or splash out on pop sticks for about $2 a pack (I got mine at Target). The white chocolate chips or melts can be found at a grocery or craft store.

It takes less than five minutes from start to finish to make a bunch of these cute little critters. It's so quick, in fact, we created a little video to show you just how easy it is to make a Peeps Pop:

How to Make Easter Grass Peeps Pops:

1. Begin by melting white chocolate melts in a bowl in the microwave, according to package directions. Generally, don't microwave for more than 30 seconds at a time without stirring.

2. Tint coconut green with a few drops of food coloring. Stir until coconut is uniformly tinted.

3. Dip Peep in the melted white chocolate, then dip in the coconut.

4. Insert a stick in the bottom of the Peep and allow the chocolate to harden.

All done!

item.title: Tutorial: Spring Hair Picks
item.dc:creator: summer
item.description:
My daughter has blonde hair all the way to her bottom. I'm always looking for cute ways to put her hair up quickly! I made these hair picks for her and am excited to see her reaction when she gets them in her Easter basket.
Project estimate:
Chop sticks , $1 Flowers, on hand or $1 Hot glue, on hand
Total: $1 and up
First pick what you would like to ...
item.content:encoded:
My daughter has blonde hair all the way to her bottom.  I'm always looking for cute ways to put her hair up quickly!  I made these hair picks for her and am excited to see her reaction when she gets them in her Easter basket.

Project estimate:

  • Chop sticks , $1
  • Flowers, on hand or $1
  • Hot glue, on hand

Total: $1 and up

First pick what you would like to put on your hair stick.  I chose flowers because I was making these for my 10 year old daughter.  You can use beads, glitter, anything!

Place a small amount of glue on the end of the stick then place decoration on it.  That's it.  Super easy and very versatile.

Have fun creating new looks and coming up with ideas on how to use these throughout different seasons.

item.title: Tutorial: Peeps Terrarium Easter Dessert
item.dc:creator: heather
item.description: Peeps are a traditional Easter candy in my family -- we must have them every year, or it isn't really Easter. I am always excited to see them at my local dollar store when I start shopping for Easter basket supplies and goodies. This year I picked up a few boxes of Peeps so we could get creative with them -- I put the boxes ...
item.content:encoded:
Peeps are a traditional Easter candy in my family -- we must have them every year, or it isn't really Easter. I am always excited to see them at my local dollar store when I start shopping for Easter basket supplies and goodies. This year I picked up a few boxes of Peeps so we could get creative with them -- I put the boxes on our table and we started brainstorming what fun things we could make with them! Our top project: a Peeps Terrarium Easter Dessert.

I have seen so many other Peeps crafts, like these Peep Brothers tell us:

I'm excited that they didn't mention our project in their list -- maybe we came up with a new way to use Peeps!

Peeps Terrarium Easter Dessert Recipe

Project Materials:

  • Peeps Bunnies, $1
  • Clear plastic tumblers, $1
  • Pudding cups, $1
  • Chocolate sandwich cookies, $1
  • Flaked coconut, $1
  • Green food coloring, on hand or $1
  • Assorted Easter candies (eggs, carrot), $1 each

Total: $7 for 8 terrariums

Save money by using things you already have on hand, like pudding, coconut, food coloring. You can bring the cost down to about 50 cents per serving if you use what you already have on hand.

How to make Peeps Terrariums:

1. Spoon half of a pudding cup (or about 1/4 cup) of chocolate pudding into a clear plastic tumbler.

2. Crumble up chocolate sandwich cookies until they resemble dirt. Spoon on top of chocolate pudding to resemble dirt.

3. Tint flaked coconut with a few drops of green food coloring. Stir until all the coconut is colored. Spread on top of cookie crumb layer.

4. Insert a Peeps bunny, a carrot candy, and a few easter egg candies to embellish your terrarium.

Alternately, create your desserts inside mason jars:

We made mason jar Peeps terrariums too, and they were super cute. If you are transporting these desserts to a party, the jar is a great way to go because you can seal it up and keep it fresh and safe while you travel. Plus, you can reuse the jar after you're done with dessert! This will add about $1 to each serving.

To find out more about your Peepsonality, visit Peeps online, or become a fan of Peeps on Facebook!

*This post was sponsored by Peeps, but project and opinions are my own!*

item.title: Tutorial: Cracked Glass Stones for Crafting
item.dc:creator: morena
item.description: This project is a family favorite. My kids *love* to "crack" glass stones with me. They don't even make anything with them most of the time, they just enjoy watching the glass crack and then admiring their handiwork. I like to paint the stones, glitter them, set them in bezels, make magnets, and all kinds of other things. But let me ...
item.content:encoded:
This project is a family favorite. My kids *love* to "crack" glass stones with me. They don't even make anything with them most of the time, they just enjoy watching the glass crack and then admiring their handiwork. I like to paint the stones, glitter them, set them in bezels, make magnets, and all kinds of other things. But let me back up a bit and first show you how to "crack" glass!

Project estimate:

  • Glass stones (purchased in the floral department), $1
  • Water & ice, on hand
  • Bowl, on hand

Total: $1

Step one: Preheat your oven to 425 degrees. Arrange your glass stones in a baking dish.

Step two: Bake the stones for 20 minutes.

Step three: Prepare a plastic bowl with ice and add water.

Step four: When you remove the stones from the oven, pour them IMMEDIATELY into the ice water. They will crack instantly.

Your stones are now ready to work with. The cool thing with this project is that the stones have cracks on the INSIDE but the outside is perfectly smooth. There are no sharp fragments or anything that will cut you. Occasionally, a stone may crack too deeply and break in half, so make several at a time.

What to do with your beautiful "gemstones"? One idea is to just set it on a bail to make a pretty, diamond-like pendant. Another is to wrap it with wire like I did in this tutorial. Let me know if you'd like to see more ideas with these stones, and I'll post them next week!

Are you ready for another awesome pin it quick giveaway?

We are!

Fine Print: Starts on March 25th at 12:01am EST and ends at 11:59 EST on March 30th. One winner will be chosen and they will get to share the other one with a friend!
The ipad mini has an msrp value of $329 No purchase necessary. Must be 18 years of age or older and a resident of the U.S or Canada. to enter. This giveaway is in no way affiliated with Facebook or Pintrest. Facebook and Pintrest will be completely released by each entrant. One entry per person. Entry includes filling out the form above including name, email and following the Pinterest boards. One entry for filling in the form. You are providing the information to the sites involved who will in no way sell or give your information to anyone including Facebook or Pintrest. Winner will be chosen using random.org. and will be notified via email within 48 hours of the giveaway close. Winners will be announced on the post, not on Facebook. The winner must respond within 48 hours of receiving the email or a new winner will be chosen. No purchase necessary.

item.title: Tutorial: Quick Fabric Wall Art
item.dc:creator: summer
item.description: Who has been in this scenario before? Your walking through Dollar Store and you children find something they can't live without. It's only a dollar so you say ok. Then it sits in the bag for months until you finally decided to give it to Goodwill, throw it away or reinvent it. The latest must-have for my children were some mounted canvas wall picture they could color themselves. ...
item.content:encoded:
Who has been in this scenario before?  Your walking through Dollar Store and you children find something they can't live without.  It's only a dollar so you say ok.  Then it sits in the bag for months until you finally decided to give it to Goodwill, throw it away or reinvent it.  The latest must-have for my children were some mounted canvas wall picture they could color themselves.  With a little fabric and Mod Podge, I now have new art for my bathroom.

Project estimate:

  • Fabric, on hand or $1 and up
  • Wall coloring art, $1 each
  • Mod Podge, on hand

Total: $1 and up

First cut the fabric to fit pictures leaving enough on the edges to fold over.

Next spread Mod Podge evenly over the entire surface including sides.

Finally place fabric over pictures and smooth down.  Work the fabric from the middle to the sides to release any bubbles. For the edges smooth over by pinching corners and then snip the left over fabric.

Now its ready to hang any where you need a little extra color.  Optionally, you can also add embellishments at this point to give it a little more personality.

item.title: A Simple Storage Solution with Rubbermaid
item.dc:creator: heather
item.content:encoded:
This post brought to you by Rubbermaid® All AccessTM Organizers. All opinions are 100% mine.

Organization has proven to be one of the most difficult challenges of being an adult. (I'm lucky that's my biggest problem, I guess.) But really, it can be overwhelming and discouraging to find "a place for everything and everything in its place."

This is a picture of one tiny section of my office shelves. You can see that the bins don't match, and that to get to anything, I have to move everything else. Anyone else have to do the "plastic bin shuffle" when they need to get something out of their "organized" office?

And my office isn't the only place that is organizationally challenged. The problem continues around the house in places like our dining room, the master bathroom, and our boys' bedroom closet.

We have toys contained inside these canvas zip-up boxes that have windows inside them. It's nice to see what's inside, but we still have to shuffle the boxes around whenever we want to get to one and open it up.

Rubbermaid® All AccessTM storage containers might just be a solution for our organizational needs:

Stackable, and easily accessible from the front of the bin, so you don't have to shuffle things around to get at what you really need.

They come in small (11 gallon) or medium size (14 gallon), and come in three colors. You can use Rubbermaid® All AccessTM organizers anywhere in your home, from craft rooms, to closets, to mud rooms, ro kids' bedrooms. Anywhere you need some storage, and regular access to your stuff!

You can buy these Rubbermaid® All AccessTM organizers at Walmart stores across the USA.

item.title: Make Wire Jewelry with Clothespins
item.dc:creator: rhonda
item.description: I have been known to tear apart clothespins to use the wooden bits for various projects. But what about the metal spring part? Mine usually end up in the recycling bin - but not anymore! The ever-so-clever Michelle from Mich L. in L.A. was playing around with them recently and came up with a delightful jewelry design. The best part? No tools required! (Seriously!) [how ...
item.content:encoded:
I have been known to tear apart clothespins to use the wooden bits for various projects. But what about the metal spring part? Mine usually end up in the recycling bin - but not anymore! The ever-so-clever Michelle from Mich L. in L.A. was playing around with them recently and came up with a delightful jewelry design. The best part? No tools required! (Seriously!) [how to make wire jewelry with clothespins]

Project estimate:

  • Clothespins, on hand or $1
  • Beads, on hand or $1
  • Chain or other jewelry findings, on hand or $1 and up

Total: Free and up

item.title: Make Bottle Cap Coasters (and 9 other bottle cap crafts!)
item.dc:creator: carissa
item.description: Bottle caps have such neat little architectural details they practically cry out to be saved. But if you're like me, you've got a sizable collection and no idea what you're going to do with it! Luckily, Heather wrote a great post over at Home Made Simple with 10 great bottle cap craft ideas including the adorable coasters pictured above. [how to make bottle cap coasters ...
item.content:encoded:
Bottle caps have such neat little architectural details they practically cry out to be saved. But if you're like me, you've got a sizable collection and no idea what you're going to do with it! Luckily, Heather wrote a great post over at Home Made Simple with 10 great bottle cap craft ideas including the adorable coasters pictured above. [how to make bottle cap coasters and 9 other bottle cap crafts]

Project estimate:

  • Bottlecaps, on hand
  • Glue, on hand
  • Extras such as cork, magnets, pushpins, on hand or $1 and up

Total: Free and up!
